prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ScienceGoal1: Polarized dust emission mapping in Lupus 1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator configuration is the standard for polarization observations in band 6.

From the SOLA catalog the sources that we have selected are compact with sizes about, or less, than 10 arcsec. Given the on-axis polarization restriction for cycle 3, the limited FOV of 1/3 of the primary beam is about 10 arcsec for band 6. Thus, 0.75 arcsec resolution gives a good comprimise between resolution to sample the polarized flux and integration time per source. This resolution will give us sufficient independent beams to derive the morphology of the field within the 10 arcsec FOV that we will acquire.

To correctly calibrate the instrumental polarization, or D-terms, an ALMA polarization observation requires a minimum of 3 hours to achieve sufficient parallactic angle coverage for the calibration source. Hence, we can use this time very effectively by cycling throughout a list of targets until the required noise limit is reached. The unprecedent sensitivity of ALMA will allow us to obtain polarized emission at higher significant signal to noise than was previously possible with other instruments. Based on BLAST-POL results, the expected polarization level is about 5%, which for our threshold of 100 mJy is about 0.2 mJy. Now considering the required angular resolution of 0.75 arcsec, the average sensitivity per synthesized beam is about 30 micro Jy. Additionnaly, it has been shown by the ALMA commisioning team (where the P.I. of this proposal is leading the polarization comissioning effort) that the D-terms in band 6 have an amplitude no larger than 3% in TDM mode and thus, 0.1% polarization accuracy is achivable on-axis. Thus, using a conservative calibration overhead of 40% we can achieve 30 micro Jy rms noise level for each of our 10 sources in 15 minutes per source for a 5 sigma signal-to-noise in the polarized flux, which in total is about 6 hrs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal2: Molecular line mapping in Lupus 1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Getting 0.1 km/s in C18O(2-1) will give us enough channels to fit a radiative transfer model even if the emission is just thermal. From Hara et al. 1999, we know for our sample the line-widths are in excess of 1 km/s. Now as we expect that 12CO(2-1) will have non-thermal linewidths, a spectral resolution of 0.7 km/s is enough to detect outflows toward these cores.

1 arcsec angular resolution gives a good compromise between integration time and line detection. As core sizes are expected to be in the order of 10 arcsec, this resolution gives us enough independent beams to determine the rotational axis and to detect outflows.

In order to map the rotational structures, including possible outflows, in these cores. We have set to observe the main kinematic tracers in band 6, 12CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1). The line sensitivity of 0.18 K rms should allow us to detect C18O(2-1) toward the sample cores; while obtaining good signal to noise in the line wings of 12CO(2-1) for outflowing motions. While not critical for this proposal goals, we may get DCO+(3-2) as well from the brightest cores at this sensitivity level.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: As part of a long term study of the nearby Lupus molecular complex by the SOLA collaboration, we here propose to map the polarized dust emission from a selected set of sources in the Lupus 1 molecular cloud with ALMA in band 6 at high angular resolution. These observations intent to obtain the magnetic field morphology in the plane of the sky as well as an estimate of the field strength by using the modified Chandrasekhar-Fermi method. We will use the derived morphology and field strength, along with our high density molecular line data from Lupus 1 and lower resolution polarization data, to study the magnetic field from the large scale filamentary cloud (1 pc) to the dense cores (0.001 pc), which has not been done before. In addition, we also propose to the map the molecular line emission in order to study the rotational structures of these cores at an angular resolution comparable to that of the polarization maps. Thus, a single spectral setup allows for simultaneous observations of 12CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1), which we will use to trace the rotational axis and, possibly, outflow motions toward these cores.
